reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “fat-tailed value-efficiency” move, which is one support for the claim that (especially on linear/unbounded views) mostly-great futures are a narrow target. But this is only one pillar among several (eutopian fragility/product-of-factors; population ethics and other single-flaw catastrophes; bounded-view arguments), so even a full refutation would weaken rather than collapse the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ thesis (moderate centrality). The critique provides a plausible counterconsideration—once high-value patterns are discovered, copying/iterative optimization could create a broad near-optimal plateau—but it remains largely analogical and under-specified (e.g., it doesn’t address that fat tails could persist due to discovery difficulty, coordination/power constraints, path dependence/lock-in, or that “value efficiency” might be dominated by rare philosophical/ethical ‘right answers’ rather than engineering designs). So it modestly weakens the fat-tail premise without decisively refuting it (moderate-low strength). Relevance is moderate because it engages a Tier-2 working assumption in Forethought’s argumentation about futureness narrowness, but it doesn’t directly engage the most active Tier-3 uncertainties (e.g., compromise dynamics, lock-in feasibility, digital minds governance specifics). Overall, it’s a useful pressure-test but not a major problem for the position as stated.
title: "The fat-tailed value-efficiency premise is speculative"
